Let XXX and YYY be topological spaces and X×YX \times YX×Y the Cartesian product endowed with the product topology. B(X)\mathcal{B}\p{X}B(X) denotes the Borel sets in XXX and similarly, B(Y)\mathcal{B}\p{Y}B(Y) and B(X×Y)\mathcal{B}\p{X \times Y}B(X×Y).

  1. Suppose f ⁣:X→Y\func{f}{X}{Y}f:X→Y is continuous. Prove that E∈B(Y)E \in \mathcal{B}\p{Y}E∈B(Y) implies f−1(E)∈B(X)f^{-1}\p{E} \in \mathcal{B}\p{X}f−1(E)∈B(X).
  2. Suppose A∈B(X)A \in \mathcal{B}\p{X}A∈B(X) and E∈B(Y)E \in \mathcal{B}\p{Y}E∈B(Y). Show that A×E∈B(X×Y)A \times E \in \mathcal{B}\p{X \times Y}A×E∈B(X×Y).
Solution.

Since fff is continuous, f−1(U)f^{-1}\p{U}f−1(U) is open for any open set U⊆XU \subseteq XU⊆X, hence Borel. Thus, F\mathcal{F}F contains the open sets, so it suffices to show that F\mathcal{F}F is a σ\sigmaσ-algebra:

    XXX is open, so X∈FX \in \mathcal{F}X∈F.

Conversely, if x∈f−1(Ec)x \in f^{-1}\p{E^\comp}x∈f−1(Ec), then f(x)∈Ecf\p{x} \in E^\compf(x)∈Ec. But if x∈f−1(E)x \in f^{-1}\p{E}x∈f−1(E), then f(x)∈Ef\p{x} \in Ef(x)∈E, so by contrapositive, we see x∈(f−1(E))cx \in \p{f^{-1}\p{E}}^\compx∈(f−1(E))c. Thus, (f−1(E))c=f−1(Ec)\p{f^{-1}\p{E}}^\comp = f^{-1}\p{E^\comp}(f−1(E))c=f−1(Ec), and since B(X)\mathcal{B}\p{X}B(X) is a σ\sigmaσ-algebra, it follows that f−1(Ec)∈B(X)  ⟹  Ec∈Ff^{-1}\p{E^\comp} \in \mathcal{B}\p{X} \implies E^\comp \in \mathcal{F}f−1(Ec)∈B(X)⟹Ec∈F.

    x∈f−1(⋃n=1∞En)  ⟺  ∃n:f(x)∈En  ⟺  ∃n:x∈f−1(En)  ⟺  x∈⋃n=1∞f−1(En),\begin{aligned} x \in f^{-1}\p{\bigcup_{n=1}^\infty E_n} &\iff \exists n : f\p{x} \in E_n \\ &\iff \exists n : x \in f^{-1}\p{E_n} \\ &\iff x \in \bigcup_{n=1}^\infty f^{-1}\p{E_n}, \end{aligned}x∈f−1(n=1⋃∞​En​)​⟺∃n:f(x)∈En​⟺∃n:x∈f−1(En​)⟺x∈n=1⋃∞​f−1(En​),​

Since B(X)\mathcal{B}\p{X}B(X) is a σ\sigmaσ-algebra, it follows that f−1(⋃n=1∞En)∈B(X)f^{-1}\p{\bigcup_{n=1}^\infty E_n} \in \mathcal{B}\p{X}f−1(⋃n=1∞​En​)∈B(X), so ⋃n=1∞En∈F\bigcup_{n=1}^\infty E_n \in \mathcal{F}⋃n=1∞​En​∈F.

Thus, by (1), πX−1(A)=A×Y∈B(X×Y)\pi_X^{-1}\p{A} = A \times Y \in \mathcal{B}\p{X \times Y}πX−1​(A)=A×Y∈B(X×Y) and πY−1(E)=X×E∈B(X×Y)\pi_Y^{-1}\p{E} = X \times E \in \mathcal{B}\p{X \times Y}πY−1​(E)=X×E∈B(X×Y). Thus, because B(X×Y)\mathcal{B}\p{X \times Y}B(X×Y) is closed under finite intersections,

    A×E=(A×Y)∩(X×E)∈B(X×Y),A \times E = \p{A \times Y} \cap \p{X \times E} \in \mathcal{B}\p{X \times Y},A×E=(A×Y)∩(X×E)∈B(X×Y),

    which completes the proof.
